data.text: Can You Enter the Destination in a GPS and Go?

Can you enter the location you‚Äôre wanting to travel to directly in to a bike GPS, like you can with your phone map? I‚Äôm super interested in one of the Garmin‚Äôs or a Wahoo, etc, but I‚Äôm not familiar with downloading maps and all of that. I‚Äôd love something where I can just easily enter the destination and Go. If that even exists for bikes!
Garmin Edge you can. I have the 1030 and it‚Äôs ridiculous what that thing can do
data.author: Timothy Drolet

data.text: good to know
data.author: Tim Burke

data.text: $600 is a fat chunk to spend! But I‚Äôll think about it lol
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: I‚Äôm not super experienced with it but ride with gps is good for streets
data.author: Matthew Wall

data.text: I have the garmin edge explore and you can my sister and her husband have the garmin edge 530 and can not i believe the 830 and 1030 also can input directly
data.author: Christopher Rooney

data.text: I just checked out the Garmin Explore. So you can input the location directly in to that one?
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: yes
data.author: Christopher Rooney

data.text: I‚Äôve got a wahoo, can‚Äôt remember the model, but all I do is plot a route on strava and upload it then the wahoo gps acts just like a traditional gps. Awesome stuff, even tells you when you‚Äôre about to start a strava segment
data.author: Andrew Cowan

data.text: How is it uploaded? Bluetooth with your phone or wifi in the house?
data.author: James Ritchie

data.text: think you‚Äôve got a plot a route on strava on a desktop pc then upload to wahoo from the pc, haven‚Äôt used it in a while but think it does it via Bluetooth or a cabled connection .
data.author: Andrew Cowan

data.text: Okay, thanks for the insight.
data.author: James Ritchie

data.text: I have a garmin 530 and really don't like it. Its not very intuitive to use and the trailforks integration is very clunky and unreliable. Which is a shame as I bought it instead wahooo because of trail forks. Yes, it can auto navigate to a destination, but it's not very good at it. Best option is to create a route on ridewithgps and manually load it in. I wouldn't trust the garmin as my only navigation tool if I was to get lost. I always have maps saved on my phone. I'd suggest trying to demo one first... Maybe you want dislike it like I do... Many other people seem to love the garmin. I'd go wahoo if I was to buy again.
data.author: GP McGee

data.text: same exact disappointing experience with the 530. Temporarily using ridewithgps on my iPhone.
data.author: Dean Wolfgang

data.text: also disappointed in 530, can not enter coordinates. Really painful to scroll around the map. Luckily only paid equivalent of $5 for mine
data.author: Paul Bekker

data.text: Hammerhead karoo has a search and navigate function very similar to maps on a phone
data.author: George Eglesfield

data.text: I chose the garmin edge 830 over the 530 for this reason. The 830 and 1030 models have routing capabilities which the 530 lacks. Meaning you have to preload your route into your device having created it in your phone or computer before. While the 830 and 1030 models you can input a point of interest ( lodging, restaurants or alike), street adresses or gps coordinates and it will create a route to follow. Just be aware of settings on your device. You can choose shortest route in distance, time or avoid heavy traffic highways.
data.author: Andri Freyr Sigur√∞sson

data.text: That‚Äôs awesome. This is exactly what I‚Äôm wanting. I don‚Äôt want to have to deal with downloading maps, etc. I‚Äôd love something simply like your phone map, entering the info!
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: I think I may actually go with the 830. What are your honest thoughts about it?
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: use it both while training on my roadbike and for navigation while touring. Does both jobs well and cant really fault it. Mine came with european maps pre installed as that is where I live. If you buy it new it should have maps installed which correlates to your part of the world. If you are planning on using it on international travel then you probably need to install corresponding maps for it.
data.author: Andri Freyr Sigur√∞sson

data.text:
I have a Wahoo Element. I upload routes from bikepacking.com directly to it. I believe you can use MapMyWalk.com to create a route and upload it as well but I haven‚Äôt done it yet.
BIKEPACKING.com - Bikepacking Routes, Gear, Inspiration
bikepacking.com
data.author: Darren Weimer

data.text: I‚Äôve been torn between that device and the Garmin Edge 830!
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: Not sure what you're asking, but in 44,000 miles in the United States, Ride with GPS is easily the best I've found, though for route planning Google Maps is probably my primary.
data.author: James Mcginley

data.text: OP is saying they don't want to route plan, they just want to enter the destination, and go, much like using Google Maps to navigate in daily life.
data.author: Clint Zarnosky

data.text: I think they don't understand the term route plan. I'm guessing it's something that I just don't know about or used. Having said that, in Ride with GPS if I don't like the route that it automatically provides if I just provide an endpoint, I find that if I provide a starting location, and then once or twice or 10 or 20 times touch on the map, the places on the road that I want to go it lays down that route.
data.author: James Mcginley

data.text: hi James, I use Google on my phone, but despite indicating I‚Äôm cycling its directed me to motorways. Dangerous üö¥üò±üò±üò±üò±. Otherwise it‚Äôs ok
data.author: Chris Kelly

data.text: I presume you know about how to set car to avoid highways and or tolls?
data.author: James Mcginley

data.text: No problems today, the motorway is on the other side of the valley üòÄüòÄüòÄüö¥üö¥
data.author: Chris Kelly

data.text: Google Maps is my go-to. Its biking directions are usually pretty spot on.
data.author: Dave Elmstrom

data.text: Several of them can - including Lezyne, which sits mid way in price point and has excellent battery life. I prefer to use Komoot - both for instant destination mapping (what you just asked for) and more complex route planning. Do it on your phone and just press send - integrates with your GPS with turn by turn navigation
data.author: Simon Usher

data.text: same. I'm pretty sure it's faster than typing the address on a less ergonomic device and route is more accurate.
data.author: Nicolas Ledoux

data.text: Best option is using an app on your phone then sync it to your GPS (pretty easy with Wahoo or Garmin). Or you can try to use in-gps navigation but : - only on higher end GPS - typing the address sucks - algorithm are not as good as phone app
data.author: Nicolas Ledoux

data.text: As people already wrote it before, the Garmin 830 and 1030 can plan a route. It kinda works, but it is not that great... I use it only when I am really lazy, and kinda now the general direction. It is much better to do the planning in komoot, but this app needs internet access, but the garmin does not, it has built in map.
data.author: V√°nyi D√°niel Attila

data.text: I can do it on my Garmin 830. Not sure I trust it blindly however.
data.author: Nbs Guy

data.text: I would probably rather trust Google for that. But I would almost always plan my routes on Ride With GPS ahead of time. Not what you are asking for though.
data.author: Nbs Guy

data.text: Wahoo (bolt) has exactly this function. Under routes hit "take me to" and select the destination on map. It routes based on distance but also bike lanes, and I suspect some popular travel routes. I've found it to be very intuitive, and often takes me new ways to familiar destinations, through side streets and sometimes neat connector trails. Keeps me off the heaviest car traffic routes for the most part which is great.
data.author: Alex Paterson

data.text: Well, as it turns out, you can use your phone for navigation when riding a bicycle too!
data.author: Jacob Ashton

data.text:
Dude get a Quadlock case. You have all of the functionality of your phone, but mounted on your bike. Super sturdy, would never consider a Garmin given its small screen etc. https://www.quadlockcase.com/collections/shop-cycle/products/iphone-bike-kit-all-devices
Bike Kit - All iPhone Devices
quadlockcase.com
data.author: Taylor Barton

data.text: I actually just bought the Quadlock OutFront Pro mount. I love it! I plan on mounting it so I can use my phone for music, etc. but I‚Äôd still like a seperate device for navigation so I don‚Äôt kill my battery life.
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: Ride with gps has ‚Äúuser generated‚Äù public libraries that you can search and download. The ‚Äúpremium‚Äù subscription lets you modify maps and add waypoints, hotels and so forth. It‚Äôs not really a ‚Äúpoint and go‚Äù app but it‚Äôs really great for both recording a ride that you later want to modify and share and or planning a ride ahead of time and sharing with others. Not exactly answering the question you‚Äôve asked but I agree with James that‚Äôs ridewithgps is very useful.
data.author: Sean McLenidoodle
